qas.question: Why has Unicode been criticized for not separately encoding forms of kanji?

answers.text: complicates the processing of ancient Japanese and uncommon Japanese names
alternative encodings that preserve the stylistic differences between Chinese, Japanese, and Korean characters

qas.question: What perception does the unification of glyphs cause?

answers.text: the languages themselves, not just the basic character representation, are being merged

qas.question: What does Unicode encode instead of characters?

plausible_answers.text: the visual representations of the basic character that often vary from one language to another

qas.question: What alternative has become popular in Japan?
What languages do not suffer from the unification of glyphs?
What are being merged alongside just the glyphs?

context: Unicode has been criticized for failing to separately encode older and alternative forms of kanji which, critics argue, <a0_0>complicates the processing of ancient Japanese and uncommon Japanese names<a0_0/>. This is often due to the fact that Unicode encodes characters rather than <b3_0>glyphs<b3_0/> (<b4_0>the visual representations of the basic character that often vary from one language to another<b4_0/>). Unification of glyphs leads to the perception that <a2_0><b7_0>the languages themselves<b7_0/>, not just the basic character representation, are being merged<a2_0/>.[clarification needed] There have been several attempts to create <a1_0>alternative encodings that preserve the stylistic differences between <b6_0>Chinese, Japanese, and Korean<b6_0/> characters<a1_0/> in opposition to Unicode's policy of Han unification. An example of one is <b5_0>TRON<b5_0/> (although it is not widely adopted in Japan, there are some users who need to handle historical Japanese text and favor it).
